= 0.4.1 | latest_release_date = {{release date|2010|08|28}}http://freshmeat.net/projects/oksh }} The '''Korn shell''' ('''ksh''') is a [[Unix shell]] which was developed by [[David Korn (computer scientist)|David Korn]] ([[Bell Labs|AT&T Bell Laboratories]]) in the early 1980s and announced at [[USENIX Annual Technical Conference|USENIX]] on July 14, 1983. Other early contributors were AT&T Bell Labs developers Mike Veach, who wrote the [[emacs]] code, and Pat Sullivan, who wrote the [[vi]] code. {{Cite book | last = Bolsky | first = Morris I. | last2 = Korn | first2 = David G. | title = The KornShell Command and Programming Language | publisher = Prentice Hall | year = 1989 | location = Englewood Cliffs, NJ | chapter = Acknowledgements | pages = ''xii'' | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-13-516972-0 }} ksh is backwards-compatible with the [[Bourne shell]] and includes many features of the [[C shell]] as well, such as a [[command history]], which was inspired by the requests of Bell Labs users. == Design == The main advantage of ksh over the traditional Unix shell is in its use as a programming language. Since its conception, several features were gradually added, while maintaining strong backwards compatibility with the [[Bourne shell]]. The ''ksh93'' version supports [[associative array]]s and built-in [[floating point|floating point arithmetic]]. For interactive use, ksh provides the ability to edit the command line in a [[WYSIWYG]] fashion, by hitting the appropriate cursor-up or previous-line key-sequence to recall a previous command, and then edit the command as if the users were in edit line mode. Three modes are available, compatible with [[vi]], [[emacs]] and [[XEmacs]]. ksh aims to respect the ''Shell Language Standard'' ([[POSIX]] 1003.2 "Shell and Utilities Language Committee"). == History == Until 2000, Korn Shell remained AT&T's [[proprietary software]]. Since then it has been [[open source software]], originally under a license particular to AT&T but, since the 93q release in early 2005, it has been licensed under the [[Common Public License]]. Korn Shell is available as part of the AT&T Software Technology (AST) Open Source Software Collection. As ksh was initially only available through a proprietary license from AT&T, a number of free and open source alternatives were created. These include the public domain ''pdksh'' and its actively developed successor [http://www.mirbsd.org/mksh.htm mksh], the [[Free Software Foundation]]'s ''Bourne-Again-Shell'' [[Bash (Unix shell)|bash]], and [[zsh]]. The functionality of the original Korn Shell (known as ksh88 from the year of its introduction) was used as a basis for the [[POSIX]] shell standard. Although the ''ksh93'' version added many improvements ([[associative array]]s, [[floating point arithmetic]], etc.), some vendors still ship their own version of the older ''ksh88'' as /bin/ksh, sometimes with extensions. ksh93 is still maintained by its author. Releases of ksh93 are versioned by appending a letter to the name; the current version is ksh93u (released 2011-02-08); the previous version was ksh93t+ (released 2009-05-01) following ksh93t (released 2008-06-24). Some intermediate bug-fix versions are released without changes to this version string.http://www2.research.att.com/sw/download/notes.html As "Desktop KornShell", ''dtksh'', the ksh93 was distributed as part of the [[Common Desktop Environment]] with several Unix systems, including [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]], [[AIX]], and [[HP-UX]].{{cite book|author1=Bill Rosenblatt|author2=Arnold Robbins|title=Learning the Korn Shell|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=5nMCY272chUC&pg=PR8|year=2002|publisher=O'Reilly Media, Inc.|isbn=9780596001957|pages=viiiâix|edition=2}} This version also provide shell-level mappings for [[Motif (widget toolkit)|Motif]] widgets. It was intended as competitor to [[tcl/tk]].{{cite book|author=J. Stephen Pendergrast|title=Desktop KornShell graphical programming|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=O6xQAAAAMAAJ|year=1995|publisher=Addison-Wesley|isbn=9780201633757|page=359}} == Uses and variants == There are also two modified versions of ksh93 which add features for manipulating the [[graphical user interface]]: ''dtksh'' which is part of [[Common Desktop Environment|CDE]] and ''tksh'' which provides access to the [[Tk (computing)|Tk]] [[widget toolkit]]. ''mksh'' ([[MirOS BSD|MirBSD]] [[ksh|Korn Shell]]) is an actively developed, [[MirOS Licence|BSDish-licensed]], flavour of ''ksh''. It is a direct descendant from the [[OpenBSD]]'s ''/bin/ksh'' and heir of [[pdksh]]. ''mksh'' development focuses on code portability, security fixes, [[UTF-8]] support, and tries to avoid [[feature creep]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mirbsd.org/mksh_old.htm#contrib |title=mksh development |publisher=mirbsd.org |date= |accessdate=2011-06-21}} It will, however, track POSIX closely and implement many ''ksh93'' and some ''bash'' or ''zsh'' extensions. It is available for many [[unix-like]] operating systems{{cite web|url=http://www.mirbsd.org/mksh_bld.htm |title=mksh tested on various platforms |publisher=mirbsd.org |date= |accessdate=2011-06-21}} and is a default shell of [[MirOS BSD]], [[FreeWRT]], [[MidnightBSD]], Android-x86, [[Android (operating system)|Android]] 3.0 (Honeycomb) and possibly the not-yet-released Android 4 (Ice Cream). ''oksh'' is a port of [[OpenBSD]]'s ''/bin/ksh'' to GNU/Linux which only contains enough modifications so that the code can compile under a GNU/Linux system. It is used as the default shell in [[DeLi Linux]]. ''SKsh'' is an [[AmigaOS]] version, that offers several Amiga-specific features such as [[ARexx]] interoperability. [[MKS Inc.]]'s ''MKS Korn shell'' is another proprietary ksh reimplementation. It was included with [[Microsoft]]'s [[Microsoft Windows Services for UNIX|Services for Unix]] (SFU) up to version 2.0. According to David Korn, the MKS Korn shell was not fully compatible with his own Korn shell implementation in 1998.{{cite web|url=http://slashdot.org/articles/01/02/06/2030205.shtml |title=David Korn Tells All |publisher=Slashdot |date= |accessdate=2009-10-22}}{{cite web|url=http://lists.blu.org/pipermail/discuss/1998-August/002393.html |title=Jerry Feldman â USENIX NT/LISA NT conference attendee |publisher=Lists.blu.org |date= |accessdate=2009-10-22}} With the introduction of [[Microsoft Windows Services for UNIX|SFU]] Version 3.0, Microsoft has replaced the ''MKS Korn shell'' with a new and fully POSIX compliant Korn shell as part of the new native [[Interix]] subsystem technology.{{cite web|url=http://technet.microsoft.com/de-de/library/bb463204(en-us).aspx |title=Windows Services for UNIX Version 3.0 |publisher=Technet.microsoft.com |date= |accessdate=2009-10-22}} It is supported on [[Windows NT 4.0]] SP6a+, [[Windows 2000]], [[Windows XP]] Professional and [[Windows Server 2003]]. It is also available in the [[Subsystem for UNIX-based Applications]] (SUA) of [[Windows Vista]] and [[Windows Vista|7]] Enterprise and Ultimate Editions only and [[Windows Server 2008]].{{cite web|url=http://technet2.microsoft.com/WindowsServer/en/library/695ac415-d314-45df-b464-4c80ddc2b3bc1033.mspx?mfr=true |title=Welcome to Subsystem for UNIX-based Applications |publisher=Technet2.microsoft.com |date=2006-03-13 |accessdate=2009-10-22}}{{cite web|url=http://www.microsoft.com/downloadS/details.aspx?FamilyID=93ff2201-325e-487f-a398-efde5758c47f&displaylang=en |title=Download details: Utilities and SDK for Subsystem for UNIX-based Applications in Microsoft Windows Vista SP1/Windows Server 2008 RTM |publisher=Microsoft.com |date= |accessdate=2009-10-22}}{{cite web|url=http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?FamilyID=dc03485b-629b-49a6-b5ef-18617d1a9804 |title=Utilities and SDK for Subsystem for UNIX-based Applications in Microsoft Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 |publisher=Microsoft.com |date=2008-04-03 |accessdate=2010-10-19}} It is the default shell (/bin/sh) for SUA.http://www.suacommunity.com/SUA_Tools_Env_Start.htm The Korn shell is also included in [[UWIN]], a separate Unix compatibility package created by Korn himself;{{cite book|author=Anatole Olczak|title=The Korn shell: Unix and Linux programming manual|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=dCIJv94vXUMC&pg=PA4|year=2001|publisher=Addison-Wesley Professional|isbn=9780201675238|pages=4}} however, UWIN only explicitly support versions of Windows up to XP, included. The original Korn shell (ksh88) is the default shell on [[AIX]] since AIX version 4.{{cite book|author1=Casey Cannon|author2=Scott Trent|author3=Carolyn Jones|title=Simply AIX 4.3|year=1999|publisher=Prentice Hall PTR|isbn=9780130213440|page=21}}http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/aix/v6r1/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.aix.cmds/doc/aixcmds5/sh.htm with ksh93 available separately.http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/aix/v6r1/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.aix.baseadmn/doc/baseadmndita/korn_shell_enhanced.htm == See also == * [[Comparison of computer shells]] * [[test (Unix)]] == References == {{reflist}} == Further reading == * {{cite book|author1=Morris I.
